Jeff,

To do sensitivity analysis on each reaction in a mechanism, the
M-fa=
ctors can be adjusted and the problem solved in a loop over all
reactions. =
 This is known as the "brute-force" method of sensitvity
analysis, but for =
my stagnation-flame simulations, it can be finished in
a matter of hours.

=
An example script from a stagnation flame simulation is:

M=3D1.5
for i in =
range(0,175):
	f.restore('run334_SDmech_20050218_multi_refine.xml','energy'=
)
	gas.setMultiplier(M,i)
	f.set(energy =3D 'off')
	f.solve(loglevel,0)
	f.=
set(energy =3D 'on')
	f.solve(loglevel,0)
	f.solve(loglevel,0)
	write.csvwr=
iteshort(prefix+'M=3D1.5_'+str(i),f,gas)
	gas.setMultiplier(1,i)
	print 'fi=
nished solution for reaction: '+str(i)

where I restore a previously saved =
solution, increase the rate of
reaction i by 50% (choose this amount to sui=
t your application), and
resolve the problem.  After writing the output to =
a csv file (write.py
is my own script and won't work for you), I return the=
 multiplier to its
original value of 1.  In this example, I am using the Sa=
n Diego
mechanism with 175 reactions.  Note that the reaction numbering in
=
Cantera is shifted down by one.  So the first reaction will be numbered
0, =
and the 175th reaction will be numbered 174.

I don't know of an easy way t=
o do sensitivity analysis on transport or
thermodynamic properties.  If any=
one has done this, I would appreciate
their suggestions.

Hope this helps,
=
Jeff Bergthorson
